Dialogue.content: Hi, I'm Olivia Chang. It's nice to meet you.
Hi Olivia! It's great to meet you too. How are you feeling today?
I'm feeling a bit overwhelmed with the start of the semester. There's so much going on in my International Relations classes.
I can understand that. Starting a new semester can be quite demanding. What's been particularly overwhelming for you?
I just had a seminar where I felt a lot of pressure to present my ideas, but I received criticism that felt harsh.
That sounds tough. It's never easy to receive feedback that feels critical. How did that experience impact your confidence?
It left me feeling anxious and self-critical, like I'm not good enough, especially because my mom always encourages me to excel.
It's completely normal to feel anxious about performance, especially with family expectations. Have you considered talking to someone in your family about how you're feeling?
I haven't yet. I don't want to seem weak or like I'm struggling with my studies.
It's understandable to feel that way, but sharing your feelings might provide some relief. Would you consider discussing your thoughts with someone you trust?
Hi again, I spoke to my brother Ryan about my feelings.
That's good to hear, Olivia! How did that conversation go?
It was okay, but I still struggle with speaking up in group projects. I feel so overshadowed by my classmates.
That's a common experience in collaborative settings. What makes it difficult for you to share your thoughts during group work?
I guess I worry that my opinions won't be valued, which makes me hold back more.
That's a valid concern. What if you set a small goal to contribute at least once during the next group meeting? It could help build your confidence.
That sounds manageable. I'll try to share at least one of my ideas next time.
Great! Remember, everyone's input is valuable, and your ideas are worth sharing. Let's follow up on your progress next week.
Hi! I'm back, but I've been feeling anxious again.
Hi Olivia! I'm glad you returned. What's been going on this week?
I went to a family gathering, and I felt overshadowed by my brother's achievements in medical school.
I'm sorry to hear that. Family gatherings can sometimes amplify those feelings of comparison. How did that affect your perspective on your own studies?
It made me doubt my capabilities in International Relations. I feel like I'm not measuring up.
Those feelings are common, especially in competitive environments. Have you taken any time to reflect on your own goals and aspirations in your field?
Not really. I've been too focused on his accomplishments.
Hi, I'm back! I started writing down my own achievements and what I enjoy about my studies.
Hi Olivia! That's wonderful to hear! How did that reflection go for you?
It helped me realize that I have my own goals and capabilities. I do enjoy the topics we study.
That's fantastic! Holding onto those positive reflections can help counteract feelings of inadequacy. How do you feel about participating more in class now?
I feel slightly more confident, but I still hesitate to join discussions.
That's progress! Perhaps sharing your experiences or insights on topics you're passionate about could help you engage more. What's one topic you could share next time?
I could discuss a recent environmental policy that caught my attention—it aligns with my interests in international relations.
